description.narrative: The overall goal of PAX's PoC Program is to increase the effectiveness of security interventions so that civilians have greater security. To achieve this goal, we firstly help civilians to hold local and international security actors to account. Secondly, we enable and motivate security actors to design and implement more civilian-centered protection strategies. The program's approach includes a combination of comprehensive research; facilitating inclusive and constructive dialogue; advocating at the international level to influence policy; and providing advice and training to security forces. The PAX PoC team was established in 2016 and expanded in 2019 with support from the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 19318, 3501 DH Utrecht, The Netherlands

The website of the PAX Protection of Civilians program contains general information about the program and its projects, our latest publications and blog posts, partners, and more.

title.narrative: 2019 Annual Report PAX PoC Program - annexes

description.narrative: The PAX PoC Annual Report 2019 reflects upon the first reporting period for the Protection of Civilians (PoC) program, initiated in September 2019. This document contains key annexes, including: a list of acronyms; an overview summary of the program’s results areas and corresponding performance indicators; and an organogram highlighting all relevant staff, partners, and key counterparts at the Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Ministry of Defense.

title.narrative: 2019 Annual Report PAX PoC Program - all projects

description.narrative: The PAX PoC Annual Report 2019 reflects upon the first reporting period for the Protection of Civilians (PoC) program, initiated in September 2019. This document provides detailed project-level reports for all 4 core initiatives under the program: Engaging International Actors (EIA), Human Security Survey - Iraq (HSS-IQ), Human Security Survey - South Sudan (HSS-SS), and Protection in Practice (PiP). These provide additional analysis as to the key results achieved during the reporting period, complemented by featured stories and further reflections from our partners.

The PAX PoC Annual Report 2019 reflects upon the first reporting period for the Protection of Civilians program, “initiated in September 2019. This document contains a high-level summary providing insights into the program’s overall progress during the initial inception phase; as well as relevant context analysis, updates regarding program management, lessons learned, and a financial overview.
Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Department of Stabilization and Humanitarian Aid, Human Security Standard Indicators

title.narrative: # of formal/informal institutions strengthened in the field of human security

description.narrative: Institutions: A range of international, national and local institutions that can consist of formal, state institutions (UN, police, gendarmerie, border control, parliament, ministry) or informal, non-state institutions (think tanks, civil society organization, women and youth groups, radio stations) and that seek to provide or enhance human security. Strengthened: This indicator focuses on the output level. An institution can be counted as 'strengthened' when it has received direct support from the project/programme for capacity building. Capacity building efforts can focus on support with institutional arrangements, mechanisms and policy, as well as people‚Äôs knowledge, skills and leadership abilities. Human security: The human security approach focuses on people‚Äôs security rather than national security issues, by reducing the levels of violence and the levels of fear people are experiencing. Specifically, the Netherlands focuses on the following three areas: 1) security providers and national security policy; 2) personal safety; and 3) preventing violent extremism.

title.narrative: # of people trained in the field of human security

description.narrative: People: A range of people at the international, national or local level, e.g. peacekeepers, police officers, prison wards, members of parliament, journalists, medics, deminers, risk education teachers, community focal points, members of civil society organizations, gender officers, PVE councilors, members of the Dutch Civil Mission Pool, etc. Trained: Attended a training. Training: Organized activity aimed at imparting information and/or instructions to improve the recipient's performance or to help him or her attain a required level of knowledge or skill. Human security: the human security approach focuses on people‚Äôs security rather than national security issues, by reducing the levels of violence and the levels of fear people are experiencing. Specifically, the Netherlands focuses on the following three areas: 1) security providers and national security policy; 2) personal safety; and 3) preventing violent extremism.
